columns.text:
$a)$ First, we have to find out the after-tax cost of debt which we denote with  $AD$, where the pre-tax rate $PT$ is $6\%$ and the tax rate $T$ is $23\%$

$$\begin{align*}
AD&=PT \times (1-T)\\[7pt]
&=6\% \times (1-23\%)\\[7pt]
&=0.06 \times (1-0.23)\\[7pt]
&=0.06 \times 0.77\\[7pt]
&=0.0462\\[7pt]
&=4.62\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the after-tax cost of debt is $\boxed{4.62\%}$

Now, let's find out the weighted average cost of capital which we denote with $WA$, where the common stock $CS$ is $70\%$, cost of equity $CE$ is $10\%$, preferred stock $PS$ is $5\%$, cost of preferred stock $CS$ is $5\%$, debt $D$ is $25\%$ and the after-tax cost of debt $AD$ is $4.62\%$

$$\begin{align*}
WA &=(CS \times CE) + (PS \times CS)+ (D \times AD)\\[7pt]
&=(70\% \times 10\%) + (5\% \times 5\%)+ (25\% \times 4.62\%)\\[7pt]
&=(0.7 \times 0.1) + (0.05 \times 0.05)+ (0.25 \times 0.0462)\\[7pt]
&=0.07+0.0025+0.0115\\[7pt]
&=0.084\\[7pt]
&=8.4\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the weighted average cost of capital is $\boxed{8.4\%}$

$b)$ A corporation did not hire more preferred shares since it is preferable to raise debt rather than pay a monthly dividend to preference shareholders, debt is preferred above preferred equity because the corporation receives a tax benefit on the interest paid to debt holders, dividends, on the other hand, will not provide a tax benefit to the company.

As a consequence, the corporation employs more debt and less preferred stock, the overallÂ cost of preferred stock is $5\%$, whereas the after-tax cost of debt is $4.62\%$, which would be lower than the preferred stock cost, debt is less expensive to issue than preferred shares.
